Therefore, the condition that cannot be diagnosed without a positive ANA is the one that is not typically associated with positive ANA. A. Drug-induced lupus can be diagnosed without positive ANA because it is a known side effect of certain medications and can be diagnosed based on the patient's symptoms and medication history. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is commonly associated with positive ANA, but it is possible for a small percentage of patients with SLE to have negative ANA. Therefore, SLE can still be diagnosed without positive ANA. C. Sjogren syndrome is often associated with positive ANA, particularly with anti-SSA (Ro) and anti-SSB (La) antibodies. However, it is possible for some patients with Sjogren syndrome to have negative ANA. Therefore, Sjogren syndrome can still be diagnosed without positive ANA. D.
